summary: Outlines how the council will implement the Local Plan policies and proposals, including working with stakeholders, preparing supplementary documents, managing infrastructure delivery through an Infrastructure Delivery Plan, utilizing development management powers, considering financial viability, allocating funding, and preparing annual monitoring reports.
geographic_mentions: Old Oak and Park Royal Development Corporation

summary: The council supports major regeneration and growth in the borough's four regeneration areas, working with the local community and stakeholders to ensure proposals deliver exemplary sustainable communities, meet housing and job targets, respect local context and heritage, and provide necessary infrastructure.
targets: 19,800 new homes in the period up to 2035
29,500 new jobs in the period up to 2035

summary: The Council will work to secure comprehensive regeneration of WCRA, focusing on a new high-quality mixed-use development in White City East, a major research/academic facility, regeneration of Shepherd’s Bush Town Centre, and phased estate renewal, delivering 6,000 homes and 10,000 jobs.
targets: 6,000 new homes
10,000 jobs

summary: The council will seek regeneration in White City East for a mixed-use urban quarter within a high quality environment. Proposals should include housing, employment (creative/academic), a research hub, leisure, community uses, and significant open space, integrating with the surrounding context and respecting heritage like the former BBC TV Centre.
geographic_mentions: Hammersmith and City Line railway viaduct
targets: local park located centrally of approximately 2ha

summary: The council will work with estate residents and stakeholders to secure the renewal of the estates in White City West and create a sustainable community. Development proposals should support local employment/skills, provide varied housing, appropriate infrastructure, permeable street patterns, and consider redevelopment of Loftus Road Stadium or the TA Centre for residential-led uses with community facilities.

policy_title: SHEPHERD’S BUSH MARKET AND ADJACENT LAND
summary: The council will support the retention and improvement of Shepherd’s Bush Market to create a vibrant mixed-use area, including leisure, offices, and residential uses, while assisting existing traders and re-providing Goldhawk Road businesses. Affordable housing and workspace are also required.

The council will encourage regeneration of Hammersmith Town Centre, leveraging its office and retail strengths, securing modern accommodation, improving the environment and public realm, enhancing access to the Thames, and supporting the replacement of the A4 flyover with a tunnel.
targets: 2,800 indicative additional homes
10,000 indicative new jobs

policy_title: TOWN HALL EXTENSION AND ADJACENT LAND, NIGEL PLAYFAIR AVENUE
summary: The council will work with partners to upgrade the Town Hall Extension and neighbouring land for refurbished/replacement council offices and a mix of town centre uses (retail, employment, housing, cinema), improving the King Street frontage and links to Furnivall Gardens and the river, with building heights consistent with the existing townscape.

policy_title: A4, HAMMERSMITH FLYOVER, HAMMERSMITH GYRATORY AND ADJOINING LAND
summary: The council will work with TfL to replace the Hammersmith Flyover and sections of the A4 with a tunnel, releasing land for mixed-use redevelopment (housing, employment, hotels, retail, arts/culture) that regenerates Hammersmith Town Centre. This includes improving public open space, connectivity to the riverside, and redeveloping the Hammersmith Centre West Island site with an improved bus station and two-way gyratory.

Seeks to leverage substantial regeneration opportunities within the Fulham Regeneration Area (FRA) through strategic site development for community benefit. This includes 7,000 homes and 9,000 jobs, enhancing Fulham Town Centre (especially North End Road), improving estates, and providing necessary infrastructure while respecting heritage.
cross_references: Grade II* listed Fulham Town Hall
Grade I Historic Park and Garden at Brompton Cemetery
geographic_mentions: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
targets: 7,000 indicative additional homes
9,000 indicative new jobs

policy_title: EARL’S COURT AND WEST KENSINGTON OPPORTUNITY AREA
summary: Supports the phased mixed-use residential-led redevelopment of the Earl’s Court and West Kensington Opportunity Area. Proposals should provide housing, employment, hotels, leisure, retail, cultural facilities, supporting infrastructure, green corridors, and a centrally located local park of at least 2 hectares. Tall buildings may be considered subject to full urban design analysis.
geographic_mentions: Earl’s Court and West Kensington Opportunity Area
targets: local park of at least 2 hectares

summary: The council will work with partners to secure the phased regeneration of the South Fulham Riverside area into a high-quality residential area with mixed uses (employment, small retail/leisure). This includes improving riverside access, connectivity (including a pedestrian/cycle bridge and a new Crossrail 2 station at Imperial Wharf), and infrastructure, while ensuring sensitive design.
targets: 4,000 additional dwellings by 2035
500 indicative new jobs

summary: Supports comprehensive residential-led development of the Imperial Gasworks National Grid site, with supporting community facilities and open space. Development must respect the character of the Imperial Square and Gasworks Conservation Area, protect the Grade II Listed Gasholder, improve connectivity (including a new link road and pedestrian access under the West London Line), and manage impacts on skyline and heritage assets.
geographic_mentions: Imperial Square and Gasworks Conservation Area

summary: The council aims to exceed the London Plan (2016) minimum housing target by achieving new homes through development of strategic sites, SHLAA sites, windfall sites, conversions, retaining existing stock, returning vacant homes to use, and supporting self/custom builds.
cross_references: London SHLAA Strategic Housing Land Availability Assessment (SHLAA)
targets: exceed minimum target of 1,031 additional dwellings a year up to 2025
seek at least 1,031 additional dwellings a year in the period up to 2035

summary: Permits conversions of existing dwellings into two or more dwellings if the original dwelling exceeds 120m², at least 50% of new units are 2+ bedrooms, family housing has garden/amenity access, and no adverse parking impact. Resists net loss of permanent residential accommodation. Supports reinstatement of family houses.
targets: original dwelling > 120m² for conversion
at least 50% of proposed units consist of two or more bedrooms
streets with less than 10% night-time free parking space (may restrict additional dwellings)

summary: Requires affordable housing in developments of 11+ dwellings (or sites with capacity for 11+), targeting at least 50% affordable overall. Specifies a 60% social/affordable rented and 40% intermediate housing tenure split for affordable units. Affordable homes should be distributed throughout developments. Negotiation considers viability, site specifics, and public subsidy. No net loss of social/affordable rented housing.
targets: at least 50% of all dwellings built should be affordable
60% of additional affordable housing for social or affordable renting
40% of additional affordable housing for intermediate housing
developments of 11 or more self-contained dwellings

summary: Expects all housing development to respect local context, provide high-quality, well-designed, energy-efficient homes with a good range of types/sizes and adequate amenity space. New housing must meet London Plan internal space standards. Density should be appropriate to context, public transport accessibility (PTAL 4-6 for high density), and good design principles.
cross_references: Policy OS1 Parks and Open Spaces
targets: PTAL 4-6 (for high density housing)

summary: Requires development schemes to provide a mix of housing types and sizes, including family accommodation, meeting local needs. Aims for specific bedroom mixes in social/affordable rented (10% 1-bed, 40% 2-bed, 35% 3-bed, 15% 4+bed) and intermediate housing (50% 1-bed, 35% 2-bed, 15% 3+bed), subject to viability and site specifics. Market housing should also include larger family units.
targets: Social/affordable rented: 1 bed: 10%, 2 beds: 40%, 3 beds: 35%, 4+ beds: 15% (approximate)
Intermediate housing: 1 bed: 50%, 2 bed: 35%, 3 or more beds: 15% (approximate)

summary: Requires 90% of new housing to meet Building Regulation M4(2) 'accessible and adaptable dwellings' and 10% to meet M4(3) 'wheelchair user dwellings', with M4(3) units proportionate to tenure mix. Accessible parking for blue badge holders is also required.
targets: 90% of new housing to meet M4(2)
10% of new housing to meet M4(3)

policy_title: MEETING NEEDS OF PEOPLE WHO NEED CARE AND SUPPORT
summary: Encourages and supports applications for new special needs and supported housing, including for older people, if it meets criteria of established local need, satisfactory facility standards, good public transport accessibility, and no detrimental impact on local amenity or services. Loss of existing special needs housing resisted unless no longer needed or replaced.

policy_title: HOSTELS AND HOUSES IN MULTIPLE OCCUPATION
summary: Assesses planning applications for new Houses in Multiple Occupation (HMOs) or hostels, or for the loss of existing ones, based on the quality of accommodation, impact on the locality, and the local need for such accommodation.

Supports student accommodation as part of mixed-use schemes in White City and Earls Court/West Kensington Opportunity Areas. Outside these areas, proposals are assessed site-by-site and resisted if likely to have adverse local impacts. Requires good public transport accessibility (PTAL 4-6), no loss of existing housing, no detrimental local impact (with management plan), high quality design, wheelchair accessibility, and secured occupation by students of specified institutions or affordable accommodation element per London Plan.
geographic_mentions: Earls Court and West Kensington Opportunity Areas
targets: PTAL 4-6 (public transport accessibility)

summary: The council will seek to address joint Gypsy and Traveller accommodation needs identified in the 2016 Assessment, working with RBKC and partners to protect, improve, and if necessary, increase capacity at the existing Stable Way site. Additional sites will meet Planning Policy for Traveller Sites (2015) requirements.
cross_references: Gypsy and Traveller Accommodation Needs Assessment (2016)
geographic_mentions: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea (RBKC)

summary: Ensures all new housing (new build, conversions, change of use) is of high design quality, meets future occupant needs, and respects good neighbourliness. Considers floor areas/room sizes (meeting 'Nationally Described Space Standards'), accessibility, amenity/garden space, safety, parking, flood protection, sustainable energy, durable materials, waste storage, noise insulation, and protection of existing residential amenities (daylight, sunlight, privacy, outlook). Extensions must not cause detrimental impact.

policy_title: PROVIDING FOR A RANGE OF EMPLOYMENT USES
summary: Supports proposals for new employment uses, especially in creative industries, health, bio-medical, and research sectors (e.g., Imperial College). Also supports retention/enhancement of existing employment uses, requiring flexible/affordable space for SMEs. Considers scale, local impact, employment opportunities, and economic strategies. Large office development (>2,500m²) is preferred in town centres or Opportunity Areas.
cross_references: Hammersmith and Fulham Economic Growth Plan
geographic_mentions: Earl’s Court and West Kensington Opportunity Area
targets: new office development above 2,500m²

policy_title: LAND AND PREMISES FOR EMPLOYMENT USES
summary: Requires retention of land and premises for employment or local services. Change of use is permitted only if continued use would adversely impact residential areas, an alternative use offers demonstrably greater benefit not achievable elsewhere, or the property is evidenced as no longer required for employment (considering suitability, marketing for at least 12 months, and impact on employment clusters). Mixed-use enhancement of underutilised sites is acceptable if employment uses are satisfactorily retained/replaced.
targets: marketing over a period of at least 12 months

policy_title: PROVISION FOR VISITOR ACCOMMODATION AND FACILITIES
summary: Permits new or extended visitor accommodation in town centres and specific Opportunity Areas if well-located for public transport, no detrimental local impact, no loss of housing, adequate servicing, high design standard, adds to variety/quality, and provides at least 10% wheelchair accessible bedrooms. Small scale hotels or those related to major attractions may be considered elsewhere under these criteria.
geographic_mentions: Earl’s Court and West Kensington Opportunity Area
targets: at least 10% of hotel bedrooms designed as wheelchair accessible

policy_title: LOCAL EMPLOYMENT, TRAINING AND SKILLS DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVES
summary: Requires major developments and larger employment-generating developments (including visitor accommodation) to provide appropriate employment, training, and skills initiatives for local people of all abilities during construction and operation. Encourages local businesses to adopt the London Living Wage.

policy_title: HIERARCHY OF TOWN AND LOCAL CENTRES
summary: The council will work to enhance the vitality and viability of its hierarchy of three town centres, 5 key local centres, 15 neighbourhood parades, and 6 satellite parades. This includes supporting regeneration, maintaining retail function, promoting night-time economy, allowing residential above ground floor, ensuring a mix of shops, appropriate scale of new development, requiring impact assessments for out-of-centre retail (>300m²), promoting shopmobility, safeguarding local shops, protecting markets, and seeking affordable retail space.
targets: retail impact assessment for out of centre retail proposals >300m² (gross)

summary: In designated town centres, changes from A class use at street level are permitted for complementary alternative uses that maintain vitality, provided no more than 40% of prime retail frontage changes to non-A1 uses. Additional A4/A5 uses, betting shops, payday loan shops, amusement centres, mini cab offices, and residential uses are not permitted on the ground floor of prime retail frontages. Non-prime frontages also have criteria. Lawful use and extant permissions are considered in frontage calculations.
targets: no more than 40% of the length of the prime retail frontage as a whole will be permitted to change to non-class A1 uses

summary: Permits changes of use in designated key local centres, neighbourhood parades, and satellite parades if complementary to the centre's function and vitality, and meets specified quotas for non-Class A1 uses (40% for neighbourhood, 50% for key local, 60% for satellite). Exceptions may be considered for premises vacant for at least 1 year with marketing evidence, based on unit's contribution, need, and shop front appearance. Ground floor residential frontages are not permitted.
targets: Neighbourhood Parades: no more than 40% non-class A1 uses
Key Local Centres: no more than 50% non-class A1 uses
Satellite Parades: no more than 60% non-class A1 uses
vacant for at least 1 year with evidence of marketing

policy_title: SMALL NON DESIGNATED PARADES, CLUSTERS AND CORNER SHOPS
summary: Seeks to retain shops and other local services in small non-designated parades, clusters, and corner shops to meet local needs. Residential use and changes to other non-Class A uses are permitted only if this does not result in a demonstrable shortage of Class A1 uses in the locality. Assessment considers proximity to other retail (400m benchmark), vacancy duration, marketing, and impact on the parade/cluster quality.
targets: 400 metres (benchmark for alternative shopping)

policy_title: MANAGING THE IMPACT OF FOOD, DRINK AND ENTERTAINMENT USES
summary: Controls operating hours for Class A3, A4, A5 food/drink establishments and arts/culture/leisure uses: generally not later than 23:00, or 24:00 in predominantly commercial areas (e.g., parts of town centres). Extended opening may be permitted if no adverse impact (especially on residents), no increased cumulative impact, good public transport accessibility, and no demonstrable increase in parking demand on sensitive roads. Start times may also be conditioned.
targets: not open to customers later than 23:00 (general)
not open to customers later than 24:00 (predominantly commercial areas)

policy_title: BETTING SHOPS, PAWNBROKERS AND PAYDAY LOAN SHOPS AND HOT FOOD TAKEAWAYS
summary: Manages the concentration of betting shops, pawnbrokers, and payday loan shops by considering proposals against Policies TLC2/TLC3 quotas and requiring no adverse amenity/character/function impact or unacceptable concentration. For hot food takeaways (A5), additionally considers proximity to existing takeaways, compatibility, and health impacts.

Permits change of use or redevelopment of a public house (A4) only after considering retail policies and assessing: economic viability (including 12 months marketing), community role, design/heritage value, and suitability for alternative uses without demolition/detrimental alteration. Buildings of townscape/historic significance must be retained. Ground floor residential use is restricted. Applicant must assess community facility needs.
targets: marketing for a continuous period of at least 12 months

summary: The council will work with strategic partners to provide high-quality, accessible, and inclusive borough-wide facilities. This includes ensuring quality healthcare (retaining/enhancing facilities like Charing Cross Hospital, securing sites for new provision), improving school provision (expansion, new free schools, special needs, childcare), and improving leisure, recreation, sports, arts, cultural, and entertainment facilities (protecting existing, supporting re-provision, seeking new/enhanced facilities in major developments).
geographic_mentions: Earls Court and West Kensington Opportunity Area

policy_title: ENHANCEMENT AND RETENTION OF COMMUNITY USES
summary: Requires new or expanded community uses to meet local needs, be compatible with the local environment, and be accessible and inclusive. Existing community uses should be retained, enhanced, or replaced, unless clear evidence shows no identified need or appropriate replacement elsewhere. Assessment considers the facility's role for community groups and requires a viability report (including 12 months marketing) if loss is proposed due to non-viability.
targets: marketing for a continuous period of at least 12 months

policy_title: ENHANCEMENT AND RETENTION OF ARTS, CULTURE, ENTERTAINMENT, LEISURE, RECREATION AND SPORT USES
summary: Supports the enhancement of arts, culture, entertainment, leisure, recreation, and sport uses. New/expanded venues must be accessible, inclusive, and mitigate impacts (noise, traffic, parking, opening hours). Retention of existing uses is sought unless no longer needed or viable (proven by a viability report with 12 months marketing). Supports temporary use of vacant buildings for creative work.
targets: marketing for a continuous period of at least 12 months

summary: Requires any redevelopment proposal for all or part of an existing football ground to include the re-provision of suitable facilities to enable the continuation of professional football or other field-based spectator sports in the borough.

The council will protect, enhance, and increase provision of parks, open spaces, and biodiversity by designating a hierarchy of open spaces (MOL, borough-wide, local importance), nature conservation areas, and green corridors. It will require new public and private open space in major developments, especially in regeneration areas, and improve existing facilities.
cross_references: Earls Court and West Kensington Opportunity Area
geographic_mentions: Earls Court and West Kensington Opportunity Area

policy_title: ACCESS TO PARKS AND OPEN SPACES
summary: Seeks to reduce open space deficiency and protect/enhance existing open space quality and access. Refuses development on public open space and strategic/borough-wide importance unless no harm to character, function, biodiversity, or visual amenity. Development on other open space resisted unless it releases a site for needed development with qualitative community gain and replacement open space is provided. Requires new accessible/inclusive open space in major developments, particularly in regeneration areas, and seeks improvements to existing spaces like Linford Christie Stadium.

policy_title: PLAYSPACE FOR CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE
summary: Prevents loss of existing children's and young people's playspace or increased deficiency. Requires new residential development with family accommodation to provide accessible, inclusive, safe, secure, well-designed, and located communal playspace on site, catering to different age groups and disabled children, proportionate to the development's scale.

Protects designated nature conservation areas and green corridors (Policies Map, Map 7, Appendix 4) from development causing demonstrable harm to ecological value, unless it achieves qualitative community gain with no net loss of native species/habitat, or provides replacement interest elsewhere. Outside these areas, proposals should enhance nature conservation interest. Planning conditions/obligations will ensure maintenance/enhancement.
targets: no net loss of native species
no net loss of habitat

summary: Seeks to enhance biodiversity and green infrastructure by maximising gardens/soft landscaping/green/brown roofs in new development; protecting existing gardens and trees; preventing removal/mutilation of protected trees; seeking retention of existing trees and provision of new ones on development sites; adding to street/public realm greening; and making Tree Preservation Orders where justified.

The council will work with partners to enhance and increase access to and use of the River Thames and Chelsea Creek. This includes identifying a Thames Policy Area, encouraging development of vacant/underused land, protecting water-dependent uses, enhancing biodiversity, safeguarding flood defences, improving the Thames Path National Trail, promoting transport uses (passenger/freight), and seeking foreshore improvements per relevant plans.

policy_title: ACCESS TO THE THAMES RIVERSIDE AND FORESHORE
summary: Seeks accessible and inclusive public access to the riverside, including through-site links in riparian development and provision/enhancement of the Thames Path National Trail (riverside walk). The walk should generally be at least 6 metres wide and accessible to cyclists if safe. Promotes retention/enhancement of access to/from the foreshore where appropriate and safe, and enjoyment of riverside heritage/open spaces. Flood defences must not be adversely affected.
targets: riverside walk should generally be at least 6 metres wide

policy_title: DESIGN AND APPEARANCE OF DEVELOPMENT WITHIN THE THAMES POLICY AREA
summary: Permits development within the Thames Policy Area (Policies Map) only if it respects the riverside (foreshore, context, heritage), is of high accessible/inclusive design standard, and maintains/enhances built, natural, and historic environment quality. Encourages greening/naturalising of river bank/flood defences (per Thames Estuary 2100 Plan). Requires a design and access statement.

Permits development for water-based/river-related activities (e.g., new permanent moorings, passenger services) if suitably located, compatible with river character/wildlife, and safe for navigation/environment/flood defences. Loss of existing facilities for water-based activities is resisted unless surplus or adequately replaced. Specific requirements for safeguarded wharves are in the London Plan.

Requires all development to create a high-quality urban environment that respects and enhances its townscape context and heritage assets. Emphasises an accessible and inclusive urban design approach, integrating good design, quality public realm, landscaping, heritage assets, and land use to regenerate places.
cross_references: Historic England Historic Environment Planning Practice Guide

summary: Permits new build development if it achieves a high standard of design and is compatible with the scale and character of existing development and its setting. Proposals must respect historical context, scale, mass, form, grain, local design context (rhythm, materials, detailing), neighbourliness, landscape, sustainability objectives, accessible/inclusive design, and Secured by Design principles.

Resists tall buildings that are significantly higher than the general prevailing height and have a disruptive/harmful skyline impact. Identifies specific areas (White City, Earls Court, South Fulham Riverside, Hammersmith Town Centre) where tall buildings may be appropriate if they meet criteria including positive townscape relationship, high architectural quality, acceptable skyline/views impact, heritage consideration, transport support, good ground-level design, sustainability, and no detrimental microclimate/environmental impact.
cross_references: Historic England guidance on tall buildings
geographic_mentions: Earls Court & West Kensington Opportunity Area

summary: Requires a high standard of design for all alterations and extensions to existing buildings. They must be compatible with the scale/character of the existing development and setting, successfully integrated architecturally, and subservient to the parent building in bulk, scale, materials, or design. Considers scale, form, proportion, materials, skyline impact, relationship to building/gardens, neighbourliness, and accessibility.

Encourages high-quality shopfronts designed to respect the building's age/style, with appropriate scale, proportions, detailing, and materials. Original/traditional shopfronts should be retained/restored. New retail developments must provide a suitable shopfront framework. Fascia/projecting signs should be appropriately scaled. New shopfronts must be accessible and inclusive.

Requires replacement windows to respect the architectural character of the building and its surroundings. The design and material of replacement windows should match the original windows as closely as possible in terms of type, size, method of opening, profile, section, and sub-division.

Protects the strategic view of St Paul’s Cathedral and important local views shown on the Policies Map, particularly riverfront views. Refuses permission for development causing harm to designated heritage assets/townscape in these views unless outweighed by public benefits. Sets criteria for applications within the Thames Policy Area affecting specific views and landmarks (e.g., from/to bridges, parks, historic waterfronts).

The council will conserve the significance of the borough’s historic environment by protecting, restoring, and enhancing heritage assets (listed buildings, conservation areas, historic parks/gardens, scheduled monument of Fulham Palace Moated site, archaeological remains, local interest buildings). Applies principles including presumption in favour of conservation, conserving setting, considering impact on non-designated assets, appropriate use changes, requiring impact assessments, respecting accessible design, and securing assets at risk.

Requires a high standard of design for advertisements, in scale and keeping with their location, without unacceptable impact on road safety. Resists excessive/obtrusive advertising affecting neighbourhood character, residential amenity, or public safety. Advertisements should normally be at ground floor level. Hoardings and advertisement shrouds have specific criteria regarding scale, impact on sensitive areas, and duration (1:1 depiction for shrouds for building works duration).

Supports the expansion of telecommunications networks while seeking to avoid detrimental impact on the local townscape. Proposals for telecommunications development must ensure apparatus is sited/designed to integrate with existing buildings, is compatible with surrounding scale/character, minimizes visual impact, avoids unacceptable impact on heritage assets/open space, and shares locations with existing facilities where appropriate.

Permits new basements and extensions to existing basements only if they meet strict criteria: not extending under the garden beyond 50% of garden depth or 50% of host building depth, set back from boundaries, single storey (except large sites), no unacceptable amenity/environmental impact, designed to minimize flood risk (with 1m soil above garden basements and SuDS), discreet lightwells, structural stability safeguarded (with CMS), and construction traffic managed. New self-contained basement flats in Flood Zone 3 require satisfactory escape means.
targets: do not extend into or underneath the garden further than 50% of the depth of the host building
do not extend into or underneath the garden further than 50% of the depth of the garden
do not comprise more than one storey
minimum of one metre of soil above any part of the basement beneath a garden

summary: Requires all major developments to implement energy conservation by following London Plan sustainable energy policies and meeting CO2 reduction targets. This includes effective passive design, detailed Energy Assessments, minimizing CO2 from heating/cooling systems (assessing decentralised energy/CHP feasibility), and using on-site renewables. Payments in lieu may be accepted if targets aren't met on-site. Encourages Passivhaus standards for Energy Strategies.
targets: London Plan’s CO2 reduction targets

summary: Requires major developments to implement sustainable design and construction measures by following London Plan policies. This includes minimizing energy use, effective resource use (water, aggregates), sustainable material sourcing, prefabrication, reducing pollution/waste, promoting recycling, conserving/promoting biodiversity, ensuring user comfort/security, and avoiding natural hazard impacts. Requires Sustainability Statements (or BREEAM equivalent). Encouraged for non-major developments.
cross_references: London Plan sustainable design and construction policies
Mayor of London’s SPGs on Sustainable Design and Construction and control of dust and emissions during construction and demolition – July 2014

policy_title: MINIMISING FLOOD RISK AND REDUCING WATER USE
summary: Requires developments to reduce water use and minimise flood risk. Mandates site-specific Flood Risk Assessments (FRAs) for developments in Flood Zones 2/3, >1ha in FZ1, SWMP hotspots, or with subterranean elements at groundwater risk. FRAs must assess all flood sources, integrate proofing, and address NPPF requirements (including Exception Test). Restricts basement flats in Flood Zone 3/high-hazard SWMP areas unless escape is satisfactory. Requires groundwater protection, waterproofing for subterranean elements, non-return valves for vulnerable developments, demonstration of water/wastewater capacity, adherence to Thames Estuary 2100 Plan, and water-efficient fittings/rainwater harvesting.
cross_references: Environment Agency’s Groundwater Source Protection Zones 1 or 2
targets: developments over 1 hectare in size in Flood Zone 1

policy_title: MINIMISING SURFACE WATER RUN-OFF WITH SUSTAINABLE DRAINAGE SYSTEMS
summary: Requires all new development to manage surface water run-off as close to source and on the surface as practicable, following the London Plan drainage hierarchy. Major developments must implement SuDS to achieve greenfield run-off rates for storms up to 1 in 100 year event (plus climate change allowance). Other developments must maximise attenuation, especially in flooding hotspots or if increasing impermeable area. SuDS should also benefit biodiversity, amenity, recreation, water efficiency, and safety. New outdoor hardstanding must be permeable. Flat roofs should be living roofs. SuDS must be maintained for their lifetime.
targets: reduction in peak run-off to greenfield run off rates for storms up to the 1 in 100 year event (plus climate change allowance)

summary: Requires assessment of water quality where a private water supply or distribution system is proposed as part of a development. Any required treatment must be identified, and an on-going monitoring and maintenance plan established to ensure compliance with relevant directives and protect health and environment.

The council will pursue sustainable waste management by planning to manage its London Plan waste apportionment (247,000 tonnes/annum in LBHF by 2036), promoting sustainable waste behaviour, continued use of the WRWA Smuggler’s Way facility, and seeking sustainable transport of waste/recyclables, maximizing River Thames use where possible.
targets: manage 247,000 tonnes per annum of waste in LBHF by 2036

summary: Requires all new developments to include suitable facilities for managing waste generated by the development, including collection and storage of separated waste and feasible on-site energy recovery. Developments must minimize waste, provide convenient recycling/composting facilities. Major proposals need on-site management for commercial/industrial streams. Sustainable construction/demolition waste practices (segregation, re-use, recycling) are encouraged, with details expected for larger demolition sites.

Ensures protection of new and existing residents by rejecting proposals involving hazardous substances that pose unacceptable health/safety risks to neighbouring land occupants, and rejecting developments near existing establishments if future occupants would face unacceptable risk. Development must account for major hazards identified by the Health and Safety Executive, specifically Swedish Wharf, Townmead Road.

Requires a site assessment and report for development on or near potentially contaminated land, or for sensitive uses, to establish contamination nature/extent. Development is permitted only if practicable and effective measures are taken to treat, contain, or control contamination to prevent unacceptable risk to occupiers/neighbours, structural integrity, water bodies, or spread of contamination. Agreed measures must be completed as the first step of development.

Seeks to reduce potential adverse air quality impacts from new developments by requiring air quality assessments considering pollution impacts on/from the site and exposure levels. Mandates mitigation for emissions (NOx, PM) if worsening local air quality or contributing to objective exceedances. Requires measures to reduce exposure for occupants, developments to be 'air quality neutral', and decentralised energy schemes to have acceptable air quality impact. CHP systems are not prioritised if other air quality neutral technologies are better.
cross_references: Government’s air quality objective concentration targets
Council’s Local Air Quality Management Plan

summary: Controls noise and vibration impacts by locating sensitive development appropriately and protecting it via design, layout, materials, and insulation. Normally resists noise-sensitive development where adversely affected by noise unless adequate mitigation is proven without compromising quality. Resists noise-generating development if it materially increases noise for sensitive uses. Requires noise assessments and mitigation details where necessary; outline applications usually unacceptable if mitigation is needed.

Controls adverse impacts from lighting by requiring all developments with external lighting proposals (signs, advertisements, security/flood lights) to submit details showing it is appropriate for use, provides minimum necessary light, is energy efficient, and provides adequate protection from glare/light spill to sensitive receptors like residential properties and Nature Conservation Areas (including River Thames).

Requires all proposed developments to demonstrate no undue detriment to the general amenities of existing surrounding occupiers, particularly where commercial/service activities are near residential properties. In mixed-use developments, similar protection applies to prospective residents/users from on-site activities. Requires mitigation measures for potential nuisances (smoke, fumes, dust, steam, light, vibration, smell, noise, spillage) to ensure they will not occur.

The council will work with strategic partners to improve transportation provision, accessibility, and air quality by improving cycling/walking opportunities and connections for bus, underground, national, and regional rail. Major scheme targets include Crossrail 2 via South Fulham, HS2 interchange at Old Oak, A4 tunnel, West London Line upgrades, increased River Thames passenger/freight use, and highway improvements. Borough-wide targets focus on modal shift, safe cycling/pedestrian environments, bike hire expansion, zero-emission buses, EV charging, and managing development traffic impact.

All development proposals will be assessed for their contribution to traffic generation and impact on congestion, public transport availability, and capacity. Requires a Transport Assessment (TA) and Travel Plan for developments anticipated to generate significant trips impacting local/strategic networks. Delivery and Servicing Plans should align with TfL’s London Freight Plan and co-ordinate with Travel Plans.
cross_references: Mayor of London’s Accessible London SPG

policy_title: INCREASING AND PROMOTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR CYCLING AND WALKING
summary: Encourages and supports increased bicycle use by requiring new developments to provide convenient, accessible, safe, secure cycle parking (Appendix 8) and suitable changing/showering facilities. Requires developer contributions for cycling infrastructure/Cycle Hire. Facilitates walking by requiring larger developments to provide accessible, inclusive, safe pedestrian routes within/through sites, access to river/canal, and contributions to improving local highway/walking environment.

Requires all proposed developments (new build, conversion, change of use) to conform to car parking standards in Appendix 7. Also mandates car parking permit-free measures on all new development unless evidence shows a significant lack of public transport availability. Encourages car club bays and requires minimum EV charging provision.
targets: minimum 25% of parking spaces equipped with electric car charging points
a further 25% passive provision for EV charging

summary: Requires new developments that include vehicular access to provide accessible, off-street car parking bays for Blue Badge holders, even if no other general parking is provided as part of the development.
cross_references: Mayor of London’s blue badge parking standards for off-street car parking (2006)

policy_title: BOROUGH ROAD NETWORK - HIERARCHY OF ROADS
summary: Regulates developments, construction, and other operations affecting the borough’s road network according to a defined hierarchy (Tier 1: Strategic routes/TLRN, Tier 2: London distributor, Tier 3: Borough distributor, Tier 4: Local access roads - detailed on Policies Map). Development prejudicing the effectiveness of higher-tier roads or introducing additional through-traffic on them will not be permitted. Direct frontage access to strategic routes is resisted. Proposals increasing car commuting into central London on strategic routes are resisted.

Requires all construction, demolition, utilities, and major logistic activities within the borough to work with the council in developing the scope and impact of their operations. Careful planning and co-ordination with the council are necessary to mitigate the impact of any additional traffic or potential disruption to the network, ensuring the smooth operation of the highway network. Encourages FORS recognition and CLOCS membership.

The council will seek planning contributions to ensure necessary infrastructure to support the Local Plan, using two main mechanisms: Community Infrastructure Levy (CIL) and Section 106 Agreements (S106s). CIL will be charged on developments per CIL Regulations and LBHF Charging Schedule, spent on the R123 List, Neighbourhood CIL projects, and administration. S106s will be negotiated for infrastructure not on R123 List and non-infrastructure provisions like affordable housing and monitoring.
targets: Neighbourhood CIL (up to 15-25%)
CIL administration costs (no more than the statutory cap, currently 5%)
